title: 109_hr4285
content: The Act may be cited as the "Detection Canine Augmentation Act of 2005". The Congress recognizes the importance of detection canines in homeland security for detecting explosives, narcotics, concealed humans, and cadavers in various locations like airports, ports, and stadiums. Detection canines are quick to deploy and can move easily in different areas. Detection canines are crucial for homeland security, detecting items like explosives, narcotics, concealed humans, and cadavers. They are especially useful in situations where detection technologies are not available or cost-effective. However, there is a shortage of detection canines available to assist law enforcement personnel, despite the authorization of 2,000 new Border Patrol agents each year for the next 5 years without a corresponding increase in deployed canines. The shortage of detection canines is a concern despite the authorization of 2,000 new Border Patrol agents each year for the next 5 years. Canines have been deployed to airports but need to be trained for mass transit systems. Urban search and rescue canines were effective during Hurricanes Katrina and Rita. Detection canines were effectively used in the Gulf Coast region during Hurricanes Katrina and Rita. Various agencies like the Bureau of United States Customs and Border Protection, the United States Secret Service, the Coast Guard, and the Federal Protective Service regularly utilize canines for security purposes. The Subcommittee on Management, Integration, and Oversight of the Committee on Homeland Security of the House of Representatives conducted a hearing on September 28, 2005, regarding the use of detection canines. During a hearing on September 28, 2005, the Committee on Homeland Security discussed the shortage of trained detection canines for homeland security activities. Various Federal agencies, a local transit police department, a private canine security company, and a university-based training center highlighted this issue. Increasing the number of trained detection canines is a key focus for homeland security activities. The Secretary of Homeland Security will increase the number of trained detection canines in fiscal years 2007 through 2011. This includes a 25% increase in canine detection teams at ports of entry, airports, and mass transit systems. Increase by at least 25% the number of trained detection canine teams for Coast Guard, Secret Service, Federal Protective Service, and FEMA to ensure availability during emergencies. SEC. 4. COORDINATION AND ENHANCEMENT OF CANINE TRAINING PROGRAMS. The Secretary of Homeland Security is responsible for coordinating canine training programs for various missions, utilizing existing resources efficiently, and exploring partnerships with other agencies and organizations for detection canines. The Secretary of Homeland Security will coordinate with other agencies and organizations to increase the number of trained detection canines available to law enforcement. A report on the Department's plan for canine training will be submitted to relevant committees within 120 days of the Act's enactment. The Department of Homeland Security will submit a report within 120 days of the Act's enactment on its plan to coordinate and consolidate canine training programs, including increasing coordination with other Federal agencies like the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives. The Secretary of Homeland Security is tasked with increasing the use of domestically bred canines for counter-terrorism purposes and consulting with other Federal agencies to streamline canine procurement and reduce costs.
